alert.note: Alert for Swain (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 03 at 6:51PM EST until February 05 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in North Carolina... Tuckasegee River At Bryson City affecting Swain County. .Approximately 2-4 inches of rain has fallen across the Oconaluftee and Tuckasegee watersheds over the past 24 hours which is causing significant rises along area streams. Additional rainfall of 1-2 inches is expected overnight, which will likely cause some streams, including the Tuckasegee River near Bryson City, to exceed bankfull and cause nuisance flooding of adjacent, low-lying areas tonight into early Friday morning. Rainfall exceeding 2 inches overnight may cause more significant rises and Minor Flooding may be possible, requiring an upgrade to a Flood Warning. Please stay weather aware tonight and monitor the latest forecasts and stream levels for up-to-date information. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Tuckasegee River At Bryson City. * WHEN...From this evening to Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, the Tuckasegee River will be flooding portions of Old River Rd and will begin to move into the Bear Hunter Campground near Bryson City. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:30 PM EST Thursday the stage was 7.1 feet and rising steadily. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest between 8.5 and 9.0 feet by early tomorrow morning. - Action/Advisory Stage is 8.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp
